meat.description: Wild game and livestock meat harvested by hunters and trappers.

fish.description: Freshwater and saltwater fish gathered from nearby waters.

fruit.description: Tree fruit, berries, and other naturally occurring sweets.

grain.description: Cereal grasses gathered, threshed, and milled for storage.

legumes.description: Pods and pulses for stews and long-term nutrition.

pasta.description: Prepared staple foods shaped from milled grains and water.

dairy.description: Milk and cultured products derived from domesticated stock.

eggs.description: Bird and reptile eggs collected from nests or coops.

herbs.description: Fresh greens used for medicine and seasoning.

spices.description: Seeds, barks, and roots that impart distinctive flavors.

oils.description: Pressed fats for cooking, preservation, and lighting.

stocks.description: Bone, vegetable, and fish reductions used as soup bases.

doughs.description: Prepared doughs ready for baking or frying.

sweeteners.description: Natural sugars collected for use in preserves and baking.

honey.description: Honey varieties prized for medicinal and culinary uses.

sauces.description: Prepared condiments to elevate meals and preserve goods.

kindling.description: Small twigs and shavings ideal for starting fires.

seasoned_logs.description: Split wood cured for efficient burning.

charcoal.description: Low-smoke fuel made from controlled burns.

softwood.description: Conifer trunks that are light and easy to work.

wood.description: Mixed hardwoods and softwoods of medium density.

hardwood.description: Dense broadleaf trees suited for durable structures.

pole.description: Slim, straight cuts used whole for scaffolding and fencing.

bolt.description: Short sections in varied diameters useful for firewood and carving.

log.description: Long trunks intended for milling into beams and boards.

rubble.description: Small fragments useful for infill and drainage.

fieldstone.description: Rounded stones suited for dry-stacked walls.

block.description: Cut blocks for masonry and load-bearing structures.

slab.description: Broad, flat cuts for flooring and roofing.

earthenware.description: Low-fire clay ideal for pottery and bricks.

stoneware.description: Dense clay for durable vessels and pipes.

refractory.description: High-temperature clay suited for kilns and forges.

ferrous.description: Iron-bearing ores for tools and armor.

nonferrous.description: Copper, tin, and other metals for alloys.

precious.description: Rare ores valued for trade and ornamentation.

thin.description: Light hides suitable for clothing and fine goods.

medium.description: Versatile hides used for armor and tack.

thick.description: Heavy hides suited for shields and winter gear.

wool.description: Animal fibers spun into insulating yarns.

linen.description: Plant fibers retted and woven into cool fabric.

silk.description: Fine filament fibers harvested from insects.

blends.description: Mixed textiles combining strength and comfort.

padded.description: Layered textiles and hides for flexible defense tailored to available fibers.

variant_guidance.name: Gambeson
variant_guidance.notes: Baseline padded armor that scales with textile quality; insert thin leather for extra durability.

variant_guidance.name: Winter Padding
variant_guidance.notes: Fur-lined padding that adds insulation with minor agility penalties.

leather.description: Hardened or layered hides shaped into shells or lamellae.

variant_guidance.name: Cuir Bouilli Cuirass
variant_guidance.notes: Boiled medium hides offer balanced defense; thick hides add weight but boost durability.

variant_guidance.name: Lamellar Vest
variant_guidance.notes: Scale pattern accepts bone or metal inserts when available.

metal.description: Mail, scale, or plate built from smelted metals and reinforced leather.

variant_guidance.name: Riveted Mail
variant_guidance.notes: Iron links with linen padding for general-purpose defense.

variant_guidance.name: Scale Harness
variant_guidance.notes: Copper-tin alloys riveted over leather to resist cutting blows.

wood.notes: Used for handles, frames, and simple implements.

bone.notes: Lightweight tools suited for sewing and light carving.

stone.notes: Durable edges forged through knapping and grinding.

bronze.notes: Alloy of copper and tin valued for resilience.

iron.notes: Primary workhorse metal for settlement industry.

steel.notes: Masterwork material created through high heat refining.

quality_modifiers.crude: Hand-hewn with minimal refinement; reduced efficiency and durability.
quality_modifiers.standard: Well-balanced tools produced by trained smiths.
quality_modifiers.fine: Carefully tuned implements that boost productivity.
quality_modifiers.masterwork: Artisan-crafted with superior materials and finish.

softwood.notes: Lightweight and easy to work; best for roofing, masts, and disposable tooling.

mixed_wood.notes: Versatile stock for planking and cabinetry.

hardwood.notes: Dense and resilient; ideal for beams, wagon axles, and weapon hafts.

small_game.notes: Bones suited for sewing tools and jewelry.

large_game.notes: Long bones carve into spear shafts and club cores.

marine.notes: Dense marine bones resist splintering; excellent for harpoons.
